Award.AwardTitle: CIF21 DIBBs: Systematic Data-Driven Analysis and Tools for Spatiotemporal Solar Astronomy Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The large quantities of data produced by modern solar telescopes provide a rich and rapidly growing opportunity for discovery. These large data sets create an unprecedented ability to observe correlations between phenomena that have previously gone unexplored. However, to harness the power of these large data sets, it is necessary to provide the solar physics and space weather communities with software tools that will rapidly and accurately catalog, explore, track and correlate solar phenomena.

This project develops tools for processing large volumes of spatio-temporal solar data. Initially, the team enables tracking of all solar events previously identified by an international consortium (the Feature Finding Team of the Solar Dynamics Observatory) and reported to the Heliophysics Event Knowledgebase (HEK). Next, the team develops systematic spatiotemporal characterizations of solar event types, and identifies spatiotemporal co-occurrence patterns. Throughout the project, the team disseminates the generated data, discovered patterns, and developed software tools to the community. By adding an ability to track features previously identified by an international consortium, the project has potential to advance knowledge of solar phenomena, and the impact of such phenomena on space weather.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Unexpected geomagnetic events on the Sun may profoundly alter our everyday lives, national security, industry and governance. The main areas that can be significantly affected by solar flares and coronal mass ejections are space and air travels, communication (satellites), navigation systems, and power grids.

With the launch of a space-based observatory called the Solar Dynamics Observatory (SDO, https://sdo.gsfc.nasa.gov/) in 2010, solar physics entered the Big Data era. SDO's instruments record data at a high spatial resolution and a time cadence, amounting to about 3 terabytes of data per day. The NSF funded Daniel K. Inouye Solar Telescope (DKIST, https://www.nso.edu/telescopes/dki-solar-telescope) will soon provide the community with even larger volumes of solar data.  These large data sets create an unprecedented opportunity to observe correlations between solar phenomena that have previously gone unexplored, and improve our ability to predict (and warn against) extreme solar events.  However, in order to harness the power of these large data sets, it is necessary to provide the solar physics and space weather communities with software tools that can rapidly and accurately catalog, explore, track and correlate multiple types of solar phenomena.

In this project, we focused on developing software tools for integration of SDO's big data, and generating data sets that are going to help the scientific community to perform data-driven studies of solar activity. In particular, we developed software for (1) tracking of solar events, (2) interpolation of their shapes (in between the recorded reports), and (3) the discovery of frequently co-occurring solar activity. All of them are freely available through Bitbucket, well-documented and published in the scientific literature.

Our first software module for tracking of solar events, reported to Heliophysics Event Knowledgebase (HEK, http://www.lmsal.com/hek/) by SDO-funded software, is called SolarTracker (https://bitbucket.org/gsudmlab/solartracking). We used our software to track reports of the following solar events: active regions, coronal holes, filaments and sigmoids. The major paper on our SolarTracker software module has been published in the Astrophysical Journal (https://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.3847/1538-4357/aae9e9/).

The second scientific software tool, enabling shape interpolation of the solar events, which are being reported to HEK at different/misaligned times is available to the public at https://bitbucket.org/gsudmlab/stinterpolation. The major paper on this STInterpolation module has been published in the Astrophysical Journal Supplement Series (http://stacks.iop.org/0067-0049/236/i=1/a=23).

The last piece of our software, intended for spatio-temporal co-occurrence mining, has been called SolarGrind and made available at https://bitbucket.org/gsudmlab/solgrind. This contribution has been described in the Springer's book, which is available at https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-319-99873-2.

These tools have been used to perform multiple data-driven analyses of solar activity, and remain actively used for data mining projects. To learn more about other components of cyberinfrastructure for solar data science (all developed under GNU General Public License, https://www.gnu.org/licenses/gpl-3.0.en.html) and our data mining activities, please visit: https://dmlab.cs.gsu.edu/, and https://bitbucket.org/gsudmlab/dmlablib.
